title: The Wedding at Cana
subtitle: When Jesus turns the ordinary into extraordinary

key_verse.text: This beginning of miracles did Jesus in Cana of Galilee, and manifested forth his glory; and his disciples believed on him.

cards.title: The Social Shame of Running Out of Wine
cards.subtitle: Why this wasn't a minor problem
cards.content:
In the first century, Jewish weddings lasted SEVEN FULL DAYS. It wasn't a 4-hour reception; it was an entire week of continuous celebration.

üç∑ THE GRAVITY OF THE PROBLEM:

‚Ä¢ Wine was essential for the celebration - a symbol of joy and God's blessing
‚Ä¢ Running out of wine was a BRUTAL SOCIAL SHAME for the entire family
‚Ä¢ The groom was responsible for providing for all guests during the 7 days
‚Ä¢ This shame could haunt the family for generations in a small village
‚Ä¢ Some rabbis taught the groom could be sued legally for breach of promise

When Mary tells Jesus 'They have no wine,' she's not asking for a trivial favor. She's saying: 'This family is about to be publicly humiliated. Their reputation will be destroyed.'

üìç CANA OF GALILEE:

Cana was only 9 miles from Nazareth. This wasn't a wedding of strangers. Most likely Mary and Jesus personally knew this family. Mary had an active role (supervising servants), suggesting they were close relatives.
cards.revelation_key: Jesus doesn't only perform miracles in spiritual crises. He cares about your social crises, your embarrassments, your 'I ran out of resources' moments.

cards.title: The Mysterious Response: 'Woman, what have I to do with thee?'
cards.subtitle: Why Jesus wasn't rude to his mother
cards.content:
Mary: 'They have no wine.'

Jesus: 'Woman, what have I to do with thee? mine hour is not yet come.'

üîç UNDERSTANDING THE GREEK:

The word 'woman' (gynai) was NOT disrespectful in Greek. It was a term of dignity and respect. Jesus uses it even from the cross (John 19:26).

The phrase 'what have I to do with thee' (ti emoi kai soi) is a Hebraism meaning: 'Why involve me in this now?' It's not rejection; it's a question about timing.

‚è∞ 'MINE HOUR IS NOT YET COME':

This phrase appears 7 times in John. Jesus' 'hour' is His death on the cross. He's saying: 'If I do this miracle, the clock starts running. Once I reveal my glory publicly, the path to Calvary is inevitable.'

Mary understands perfectly. She doesn't argue. She only tells the servants: 'Whatsoever he saith unto you, do it.' She trusts that Jesus knows what to do.

üí° THE LESSON:

Mary presents the problem, but doesn't tell Jesus HOW to solve it. She trusts His method, His timing, and His wisdom.

greek_words.meaning: Woman - term of respect and dignity
greek_words.revelation: It's not 'mother' because Jesus is establishing that His Messianic ministry transcends earthly family relationships.

greek_words.meaning: Hour - the appointed moment of His glorification on the cross
greek_words.revelation: Every miracle of Jesus is a step toward Calvary. He counts the cost before acting.

cards.revelation_key: Present your problems to Jesus, but don't dictate the method. Trust His timing and His wisdom.

cards.title: The Six Waterpots: Symbols of the Incomplete
cards.subtitle: Why the number 6 is crucial
cards.content:
Jesus commands them to fill SIX stone waterpots used for Jewish ceremonial purification.

üî¢ THE SYMBOLISM OF NUMBER 6:

‚Ä¢ In biblical numerology, 6 is the number of MAN (created on day 6)
‚Ä¢ 6 is one less than 7 (the number of divine perfection)
‚Ä¢ 6 always represents THE INCOMPLETE, what needs to be completed

üè∫ THE PURIFICATION WATERPOTS:

‚Ä¢ They were made of STONE, not pottery - cold, inflexible, heavy material
‚Ä¢ Used for ritual hand washing before eating (Mark 7:3-4)
‚Ä¢ Represented the purification system of the Law - external, ceremonial, repetitive
‚Ä¢ Each waterpot held 2-3 firkins (approx. 20-30 gallons each)
‚Ä¢ TOTAL: Between 120-180 gallons of new wine

‚ú® THE TRANSFORMATION:

Jesus takes the WATER (symbol of external purification) and converts it into WINE (symbol of joy, celebration, and the new covenant).

He doesn't add wine to water. He TRANSFORMS the water into wine. He completes the incomplete. He converts cold ritual into living celebration.

The governor of the feast declares: 'Thou hast kept the good wine until now.' Jesus' wine is not only sufficient - it's SUPERIOR.

scripture_connections.text: And wine that maketh glad the heart of man
And in this mountain shall the LORD of hosts make unto all people a feast of fat things, a feast of wines on the lees

cards.revelation_key: Jesus didn't come to improve your religion (the 6 waterpots). He came to TRANSFORM your life from ritual to celebration, from law to grace.

cards.title: The New Wine: Image of the New Covenant
cards.subtitle: Why the first miracle wasn't a healing
cards.content:
Why did Jesus choose a wedding for His first public miracle? Why not heal a leper or raise the dead?

üíí BECAUSE JESUS IS THE BRIDEGROOM:

In the Old Testament, God presents Himself as Israel's Husband (Isaiah 54:5, Hosea 2:19). Jesus is declaring: 'I am the promised Bridegroom. I have come for my Bride.'

üç∑ WINE AS PROPHETIC SYMBOL:

‚Ä¢ Jesus Himself will say in Matthew 9:17: 'Neither do men put new wine into old bottles... new wine must be put into new bottles'
‚Ä¢ Wine represents the NEW COVENANT in His blood (Luke 22:20)
‚Ä¢ At the Last Supper, Jesus will lift the cup and say: 'This cup is the new testament in my blood'

üîó THE CONNECTION:

‚Ä¢ First public miracle: Jesus converts WATER into WINE (Cana)
‚Ä¢ Last public act: Jesus offers His BLOOD as WINE of the new covenant (Calvary)

He BEGINS with wine at a wedding and ENDS with wine at the cross. Jesus' entire ministry is framed by the symbol of wine - the joy of salvation purchased with His blood.

‚ú® THE SILENT MIRACLE:

Only the servants (who obeyed) and the disciples knew it was a miracle. The governor and guests thought it was ordinary wine. God constantly works miracles that only those who are attentive can see.
cards.identity_statement: You are invited to the Lamb's wedding. Jesus is the Bridegroom who provides the wine of salvation - His own blood. And the banquet never ends.
cards.revelation_key: The first miracle wasn't of necessity (no one was dying from lack of wine). It was of ABUNDANCE and CELEBRATION. That's God's heart toward you.

discovery_questions.question: In what area of your life do you feel like 'the wine ran out' - that resource, that joy, that capacity you need but no longer have? Have you presented that shame to Jesus?
The servants filled the waterpots to the brim, though they didn't understand why. Is there something Jesus has asked you to do that doesn't make logical sense yet?
The 6 waterpots represent your incomplete religious system (rituals, efforts, good works). Are you trying to 'fill waterpots' or allowing Jesus to TRANSFORM water into wine?

prayer.title: Prayer of Transformation
prayer.content: Jesus, my heavenly Bridegroom. Thank You that Your first miracle was not of judgment but of celebration. Today I bring before You the areas where 'the wine ran out' - where my resources, my joy, my capacity are no longer sufficient. I don't dictate the method; I trust Your timing and Your wisdom. Transform my religious water into wine of celebration. May my life shift from ritual to relationship, from effort to grace, from scarcity to abundance. And when I arrive at Your eternal banquet, may I recognize that You saved the best wine for last. In the name of Jesus, Amen.
